C You asked me to amplify the provisional reply which I sent you on 8th March to your letter of 2nd March, We are still in some difficulty in dealing with this matter because of our uncertainty about the precise intentions of the writer of the Government of India letter. I must ask you therefore to treat this reply as an attempt to provide a basis for the elucidation of the request from India rather than as a reply to it. In the past it has, of course, unfortunately been true that independent parts of the Empire as well as foreign countries, have used protective restrictions to support their new industries but we have not had reason to complain that Egypt and Iraq have discriminated,specifically against the commerce of this country as distinct from the generality of foreign countries. We should, of course, resist energetically any attempt to treat the commerce of this country less favour ably than that of any other foreign country. But in the case of Egypt there has been legislation, actual and attempted, designed to promote Egyptian interests at the expense of all foreigners, e.g. attempts to secure effective Egyptian control of companies registered in Egypt etc., etc. 23^ In the case of China, you are probably already aware that we shall probably shortly be negotiating a Commercial Treaty, one of the main objects of which will be - as far as we are concerned - to ensure that China does not discriminate against our nationals or commerce. • D. M. Cleary Esq., India Office, Whitehall, S.W.1.In the case of Eire, although it is true that protective restrictions have been introduced which have affected the trade of this country, they were not directed specifically against this country (except for a short period in consequence of political differences connected with the Irish Land Annuities question), and we have some reason to hope that Eire will not in the future pursue a policy of protective restrictions which would, in effect, impede the trade of this country. It is to be noted that in the Eire Trade Agreement of 1938 Eire undertook that protective duties and other import restrictions should be reviewed by a Prices Commission in accordance with the principle that such duties and restrictions should be replaced by duties not exceeding such a level as would give United Kingdom producers and manufacturers full opportunity of reasonable competition while affording Eire industries adequate protection having regard to the relative cost of economical and efficient production. titleInfo.title: Ext 866/45 'Request for information about commercial relations and restrictions against British and Foreign business interests in countries which have passed from a dependent to a foreign status'

physicalDescription.extent: The file's contents are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 18; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file consists primarily of letters and telegrams between the India Office and the Commercial Relations and Treaties Department of the Board of Trade. It concerns information demanded from the Government of India regarding commercial relations and restrictions against British and foreign business interests in countries that have passed from a dependent to sovereign status.
